prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The correlator setup is chosen to cover the N2H+(3-2) line, obtain good continuum sensitivity on the low-mass cores, and include lines that can be used to search for infall towards the central MYSOs (most importantly H2CO 4(0,4)-3(0,3), E_u=34 K; see also Science Case.) We target N2H+(3-2) because it is expected to be bright enough to be detectable (see above), while avoiding the potential for confusion with emission from outflows and the ambient cloud that makes CO and its isotopes problematic. From the N2H+ studies cited in the Sensitivity section (above), we expect median linewidths of ~0.5 km/s, and propose to use 0.151 km/s spectral resolution. This setup provides sufficient sensitivity to detect low-mass cores (see above), while resolving the line across multiple (3 or more) resolution elements. (Note: the higher-frequency continuum spw is set as the representative window, so that this observing frequency sets the Nyquist sampling of the mosaic pattern. This choice results in the flag re spectral resolution and line width, even though our correlator setup is chosen to have ~3 resolution elements across the N2H+(3-2) line.)
We expect larger linewidths (>>1 km/s; Cyganowski et al. 2011, ApJ, 729, 124) towards the massive sources, and so select a spectral resolution of ~0.29 km/s for the infall tracers (with the exception of 34SO); this gives >3 spectral resolution elements across the lines. For the 34SO line, we use 4x spectral averaging to reduce the data rate, giving a spectral resolution of ~0.5 km/s; since the fitted width of the SO(6_5-5_4) line was ~10 km/s in our SMA observations, we expect a spectral resolution of 0.5 km/s to be sufficient to resolve the 34SO line.
We use FDM rather than TDM continuum windows so that we can more effectively remove line contamination, in particular for the massive cluster members (one of which is a hot core; Cyganowski et al. 2011, ApJ, 729, 124, Cyganowski et al. 2014, ApJL, 796, 2). We have selected a spectral averaging factor of 2 to reduce the data rate. The resulting spectral resolution (~1.2 km/s) is comparable to that of our SMA 1.3 mm observations; based on the SMA data, we expect ~1.2 km/s resolution to be sufficient to detect and identify line emission, and so decontaminate the continuum. Observing in FDM mode with ~1.2 km/s resolution will also likely allow the study of additional lines, increasing the scientific and archival value of the dataset.

Our goal is to detect dense molecular cores, which have scales of a few thousand AU (typical sizes of 2000-4000 AU for Ophiuchus and Serpens; Simpson et al. 2008, MNRAS, 391, 205, Hogerheijde et al. 1999, ApJ, 513, 350). A 0.5" beam corresponds to a linear resolution of 1700 AU (D=3.4 kpc, Sato et al. 2014, ApJ, 793, 72). This resolution will help distinguish low-mass cores from circumstellar disks around (more evolved) low-mass stars: we expect cores to be at least marginally resolved, while disks would be both faint and unresolved (sizescales <500 AU). With 0.5" resolution, we avoid over-resolving the low-mass cores (see also Fig. 2). The LAS (6"~20,000 AU) is specified to encompass the lower density envelopes of low mass cores (~8000 AU, Hogerheijde et al. 1999), as well as the inner regions of the massive cores known to exist in our targets. Cluster formation models predict low-mass cores within the accretion reservoir of the most massive source. As shown in Fig. 1, small (7-pointing) mosaics are sufficient to cover the areas of interest at the desired sensitivity.
Image dynamic range: Based on extensive SMA imaging (described in the Science Case), we know the total millimeter continuum flux density and the source sizes for the massive cores in our target protoclusters. We will be able to self-calibrate the data to effectively remove residual phase and amplitude errors, and the team are expert in self-calibration. Our simulations (Fig. 2, Science Case) demonstrate that we can achieve the dynamic range necessary to detect the millimeter continuum emission from low-mass cores near more massive cluster members.

The sensitivity requirement is based on the continuum flux. The requested continuum sensitivity is based on the requirement to detect the thermal dust emission from a 0.1 solar mass cold (10 K) core at the 5-sigma level, corresponding to an rms of 0.06 mJy/beam. The parameters in the OT are set for the required continuum sensitivity, for the aggregate bandwidth. (Towards low-mass cores, N2H+ lines are expected to be narrow, occupying at most ~1% of the total bandwidth.)
The corresponding (1 sigma) line sensitivity is ~10.5 mJy/beam (0.65 K) per 0.151 km/s resolution element for N2H+ (calculated using the OT sensitivity calculator for 6 minutes integration, then accounting for the overlap in mosaic pointings). Miettinen et al. (2010, A&A, 524, A91) found the low-mass core population in the Orion B9 cloud to be similar to that in nearby low-mass star-forming regions. The 9 cores they targeted (and detected) with APEX in N2H+(3-2) have a median peak intensity of ~ 14 Jy (T_MB~0.5 K). Interferometric studies show that N2H+(1-0) traces dense inner envelopes around low-mass protostars (typical scales of ~10,000 AU, e.g. Tobin et al. 2011, ApJ, 740, 45; Tobin et al. 2012, ApJ, 748, 16), and N2H+(3-2) is expected to preferentially trace even higher densities (compared to the lower-J transition; e.g. Crapsi et al. 2005, ApJ, 619, 379). Scaling the peak intensities from the Miettinen study to 3.4 kpc gives a predicted median line strength of >200 mJy/beam (>20 sigma). Estimates based on the CARMA N2H+(1-0) data in Tobin et al. yield similar values for expected N2H+(3-2) line strengths. The largest angular scale of the proposed observations is sufficient to capture the expected scale of low-mass cores, in N2H+ as well as continuum emission.
The (1-sigma) sensitivity for the other lines is ~7.3 mJy/beam (0.42 K) per 0.29 km/s resolution element (C33S, H2CO, and DCN) and ~5.6 mJy/beam (0.32 K) per 0.5 km/s resolution element (34SO). For the infall tracers (science "for free"), we expect line brightness temperatures from a few to tens of K (i.e. comparable to the upper state energies of the transitions for optically thick lines).

The correlator setup is chosen to cover the N2H+(3-2) line, obtain good continuum sensitivity on the low-mass cores, and include lines that can be used to search for infall towards the central MYSOs (most importantly H2CO 4(0,4)-3(0,3), E_u=34 K; see also Science Case.) We target N2H+(3-2) because it is expected to be bright enough to be detectable (see above), while avoiding the potential for confusion with emission from outflows and the ambient cloud that makes CO and its isotopes problematic. From the N2H+ studies cited in the Sensitivity section (above), we expect median linewidths of ~0.5 km/s, and propose to use 0.151 km/s spectral resolution. This setup provides sufficient sensitivity to detect low-mass cores (see above), while resolving the line across multiple (3 or more) resolution elements. (Note: the higher-frequency continuum spw is set as the representative window, so that this observing frequency sets the Nyquist sampling of the mosaic pattern. This choice results in the flag re spectral resolution and line width, even though our correlator setup is chosen to have ~3 resolution elements across the N2H+(3-2) line.)
We expect larger linewidths (>>1 km/s; Cyganowski et al. 2011, ApJ, 729, 124) towards the massive core in G19.01-0.03, and so select a spectral resolution of ~0.29 km/s for the infall tracers (with the exception of 34SO); this gives >3 spectral resolution elements across the lines. For the 34SO line, we use 4x spectral averaging to reduce the data rate, giving a spectral resolution of ~0.5 km/s; since the fitted width of the SO(6_5-5_4) line was ~4 km/s in our SMA observations, we expect a spectral resolution of 0.5 km/s to be sufficient to resolve the 34SO line.
We use FDM rather than TDM continuum windows so that we can more effectively remove line contamination, in particular for the massive core, which exhibits hot core line emission (Cyganowski et al. 2011, ApJ, 729, 124). We have selected a spectral averaging factor of 2 to reduce the data rate. The resulting spectral resolution (~1.2 km/s) is comparable to that of our SMA 1.3 mm observations; based on the SMA data, we expect ~1.2 km/s resolution to be sufficient to detect and identify line emission, and so decontaminate the continuum. Observing in FDM mode with ~1.2 km/s resolution will also likely allow the study of additional lines, increasing the scientific and archival value of the dataset.

Our goal is to detect dense molecular cores, which have scales of a few thousand AU (typical sizes of 2000-4000 AU for Ophiuchus and Serpens; Simpson et al. 2008, MNRAS, 391, 205, Hogerheijde et al. 1999, ApJ, 513, 350). A 0.5" beam corresponds to a linear resolution of 2100 AU (D=4.2 kpc, Cyganowski et al. 2011, ApJ, 729, 124). This resolution will help distinguish low-mass cores from circumstellar disks around (more evolved) low-mass stars: we expect cores to be at least marginally resolved, while disks would be both faint and unresolved (sizescales <500 AU). With 0.5" resolution, we avoid over-resolving the low-mass cores (see also Fig. 2). The LAS (6"~25,000 AU) is specified to encompass the lower density envelopes of low mass cores (~8000 AU, Hogerheijde et al. 1999), as well as the inner regions of the massive cores known to exist in our targets. Cluster formation models predict low-mass cores within the accretion reservoir of the most massive source. As shown in Fig. 1, small (7-pointing) mosaics are sufficient to cover the areas of interest at the desired sensitivity.
Image dynamic range: Based on extensive SMA imaging (described in the Science Case), we know the total millimeter continuum flux density and the source sizes for the massive cores in our target protoclusters. We will be able to self-calibrate the data to effectively remove residual phase and amplitude errors, and the team are expert in self-calibration. Our simulations (Fig. 2, Science Case) demonstrate that we can achieve the dynamic range necessary to detect the millimeter continuum emission from low-mass cores near more massive cluster members.

The sensitivity requirement is based on the continuum flux. The requested continuum sensitivity is based on the requirement to detect the thermal dust emission from a 0.1 solar mass cold (10 K) core at the 5-sigma level, corresponding to an rms of 0.06 mJy/beam. The parameters in the OT are set for the required continuum sensitivity, for the aggregate bandwidth. (Towards low-mass cores, N2H+ lines are expected to be narrow, occupying at most ~1% of the total bandwidth.)
The corresponding (1-sigma) line sensitivity is ~10.5 mJy/beam (0.65 K) per 0.151 km/s resolution element for N2H+ (calculated using the OT sensitivity calculator for 6 minutes integration, then accounting for the overlap in mosaic pointings). Miettinen et al. (2010, A&A, 524, A91) found the low-mass core population in the Orion B9 cloud to be similar to that in nearby low-mass star-forming regions. The 9 cores they targeted (and detected) with APEX in N2H+(3-2) have a median peak intensity of ~ 14 Jy (T_MB~0.5 K). Interferometric studies show that N2H+(1-0) traces dense inner envelopes around low-mass protostars (typical scales of ~10,000 AU, e.g. Tobin et al. 2011, ApJ, 740, 45; Tobin et al. 2012, ApJ, 748, 16), and N2H+(3-2) is expected to preferentially trace even higher densities (compared to the lower-J transition; e.g. Crapsi et al. 2005, ApJ, 619, 379). Scaling the peak intensities from the Miettinen study to 4.2 kpc gives a predicted median line strength of order 160 mJy/beam (>15 sigma). Estimates based on the CARMA N2H+(1-0) data in Tobin et al. yield similar values for expected N2H+(3-2) line strengths. The largest angular scale of the proposed observations is sufficient to capture the expected scale of low-mass cores, in N2H+ as well as continuum emission.
The (1-sigma) sensitivity for the other lines is ~7.3 mJy/beam (0.42 K) per 0.29 km/s resolution element (C33S, H2CO, and DCN) and ~5.6 mJy/beam (0.32 K) per 0.5 km/s resolution element (34SO). For the infall tracers (science "for free"), we expect line brightness temperatures from a few to tens of K (i.e. comparable to the upper state energies of the transitions for optically thick lines).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Most stars form in clusters, yet basic aspects of how this occurs remain unknown, including the relative birth order of high and low mass stars. In clump-scale "competitive accretion"-type models, massive stars and their surrounding cluster of lower mass stars form simultaneously. Thus a key, testable prediction of these models is that centrally condensed low-mass cores should exist within the accretion reservoir of a forming massive star. Using the unprecedented sensitivity and dynamic range of ALMA, we propose to test these models by searching for the 1.0 mm continuum emission from the low-mass core population associated with two young massive (proto)clusters that show strong evidence for recent shocks, active outflows, and hence ongoing accretion (both GLIMPSE Extended Green Objects, EGOs). By imaging the full extent of the associated (sub)mm clumps (~0.8 pc diameter), we will characterize the entire low-mass core population of our target clusters, down to 0.1 Msun. To measure the kinematics of these cores, we also target the N2H+(3-2) line.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00812.S, "Hiding in the Shadow of Giants: Low mass cores in massive (proto)clusters", PI C. Cyganowski B-rated Cycle 2 proposal, not yet observed as of Cycle 3 deadline
